journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment

title-group.article-title: Ship electric propulsion with a sensorless permanent magnet synchronous motor: A simulation study

article-meta.aff: 1School of Energy and Power Engineering, Wuhan University of Technology, People’s Republic of China
2School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, The University of New South Wales, Sydney, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Xinping Yan, School of Energy and Power Engineering, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan 430063, People’s Republic of China. Email: xpyan@whut.edu.cn

abstract.p: New general ships powered by electric propulsion always operate at low motor speeds. Popular sensorless vector control methods, including open loop and closed loop methods, are not reliable in this application. This is because the magnitude of back-electromotive force voltage is very small in the low speed region, and the performance of these methods is therefore significantly degraded. To overcome this problem, a high-frequency injection method is introduced in the control of the ship electric propulsion system. The injected periodic signal creates a high-frequency revolving field to act as a carrier. Then the desired information about the position angle of the motor can be retrieved. A simulation model of a ship electric propulsion system is established in Matlab/Simulink. The test results show that the newly proposed control system works stably with various ship operating conditions and robustly against speed variations. Its estimated position error is less than 0.3 rad. Moreover, the proposed sensorless vector control approach has been compared with the closed-loop-based model reference adaptive system. The comparison has demonstrated that the dynamic characteristics of the proposed control system are superior to the latter.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Mechanically propelled ships account for approximately 95% of the world’s ships. This kind of propulsion system employs a shaft line to transfer mechanical energy generated by a main internal combustion engine to the propeller. The shaft line is prone to misalignment and distortion due to the interaction of sea, hull, and marine propulsion system.1 As a result, the power transmission efficiency is reduced and the noise and vibration of ships are increased. The ship electric propulsion system is a solution to this problem. This propulsion system emerged in the early 1900s, for example, the aircraft carriers Lexington and Saratoga built in 1927.2,3 Having undergone a boom before the Second World War (WWII, 1939–45) and a recession post WWII, the ship electric propulsion technique has flourished again since the 1980s.4 Nowadays the ship electric propulsion system has become a first choice for cruise ships and several types of commercial ships, and the number of electrically propelled ships has grown explosively around the world.5
Because there is no need for shafts and gearing systems, the ship electric propulsion system has many outstanding merits including the following.5–8

list-item.p: Good maneuverability. It is very difficult to maintain a constant torque when operating mechanical propulsion systems at various speeds.9 Moreover, the mechanical propulsion systems are unable to maintain power continuity when the operation state of a ship changes.10 In contrast, the electric propulsion systems have no such problem and are flexible at all power levels.

Economic fuel cost. Generally, the mechanical propulsion systems have separate prime movers to provide propulsion and services and all main engines should keep running during the trip. In comparison all prime movers in the electrical propulsion system are designed for both duties and the system is flexible enough to increase the number of running generators according to the actual requirements. Hence, although the energy conversion efficiency of the electrical propulsion system is lower than that of the mechanical propulsion system, the power usage of the electrical propulsion is more efficient, especially at lower speeds.5 For instance, for the same power level, the ships which adopt electric propulsion systems can consume approximately 10% less fuel than those that are mechanically propelled.11 Moreover, Latorre and Cardella12 reported that the mechanically propelled ships were prone to be overpowered, resulting in high NOx emissions. In the electrical propulsion systems, since the power regulation is highly flexible and the electric power is produced under a relatively high generator speed, the greenhouse gas emissions can be reduced effectively.8

Low vibration and noise. Traditional mechanical propulsion systems often suffer from torsional vibration, longitudinal vibration, and whirling vibration caused by the long shaft line.11 The propulsion motors are installed close to the propellers in the electrical propulsion systems and hence the vibration and noise can be reduced significantly.

Simple installation and maintenance. Since the propulsion motors could be installed close to the propellers (e.g. the podded electric propulsion systems), the prime mover arrangement can be optimized in an electrical propulsion system, leaving more available space for maintenance and/or any tasks.

sec.p: Although electric propulsion systems have the above advantages, in the last decade the driven capacity of electric propulsion systems has been insufficient for many of today’s seagoing vessels and thus has limited their applications. Fortunately, breakthroughs in the field of power electronics and energy storage systems have enhanced the energy volume of electric propulsion systems significantly. Hence, in recent years the ship electric propulsion system has drawn interest from navies, shipyards and ship owners as well as engineers and researchers. The demand of the ship electrical propulsion systems has gradually increased, which indicates great potential for further development.13

To drive the propellers smoothly, the electric propulsion transmission changes the relatively high speed, low torque of the prime mover to a low speed, high torque.14 Both DC and AC motors have been employed in the electric propulsion systems.4 The DC motors often have a poor power density and maintenance record,4 while the AC motors, especially the permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) can provide a high power density, high torque to current ratio and outstanding efficiency.15 Thus, the PMSM-based ship propulsion drives have received considerable attention and are promising for industry applications.

Control technology is one of the key issues of the ship electric propulsion system. High control performance of the propulsion motor ensures the normal operation of the ship electric propulsion system and hence realizes the above advantages. For the stable control of the PMSM-based ship propulsions, a position sensor for the PMSM is necessary.6,7,14 In order to obtain the information of PMSM rotor positions, two types of sensors are used in practice. One is physical sensors such as a tachogenerator or optical encoder mounted on the PMSM rotor directly. However, the cost of the encoder may account for approximately 1/3 of the PMSM control system cost,16 resulting in high cost and complexity of the control system.12–15 In addition, a failure of the encoder decreases the system reliability and even damages the entire system.17–20 More importantly, due to some physical constraints, it is difficult to install the encoder into the marine electric propulsion system.8 Thus, this type of position sensor is not incorporated in the ship electric propulsion systems.

In addition to physical sensors, the other position sensor is the induced voltage sensing type, which extracts the rotor position information in functions of the terminal quantities from the PMSM mathematical model.6,7 The sensor uses the so-called sensorless control technique,21 where the PMSM stator itself is used as the position sensor. Since the position sensorless strategy abandons physical sensors, it overcomes the shortcomings and thus it is desirable to use this in ship electric propulsion systems.

In general, there are two strategies to achieve PMSM sensorless control. One is the fundamental harmonic excitation methods based on the back electromotive force (EMF) estimation21–23 and the other is the high-frequency signal injection approaches which use the motor saliency.14,24 The former relies on specific characteristics of the back EMF and is applicable to medium- and high-speed cases. This is because the back EMF is proportional to the rotor speed and hence is too small to be induced in the armature windings when the motor is operated at a very low speed. In contrast to the harmonic excitation methods, the latter uses the motor saliency. By checking the motor response excited by a high-frequency injection signal, the position-dependent inductance variation can be used to estimate the rotor angle.25 This approach makes the high-frequency signal injection technique capable of esti-mating the rotor position even in a zero-low speed operation. Table 1 compares the capability of this sensorless technique with a traditional control technique and the EMF-based sensorless technique. It can be seen that the sensorless control schemes can reduce the system lifecycle costs and improve its reliability. Given that ship propulsion systems are typified by a high torque at a low speed, the high-frequency signal injection sensorless scheme is suitable for this application.

caption.p: A comparison between the capabilities of three different motor control techniques.

sec.p: However, very limited work has been done to address this issue. Batzel and Lee14,15 developed a rotor position estimator for the sensorless PMSM using fundamental harmonic excitation methods. Their work was for vehicle propulsion systems. Liu et al.26 investigated the sensorless control scheme of the ship electric propulsion system and Guo et al.27 adopted the flux-observer-based position sensorless control scheme for the ship electrical propulsion system. The fundamental harmonic excitation methods were adopted in their work and thus, due to the drawbacks of the back EMF estimators, the control performance of the electrical propulsion system was not presented in the low speed region (e.g. <50 rpm). In order to enhance the sensorless control in a low speed range, the high-frequency voltage signal injection approach is introduced into the ship electric propulsion system in this paper. Numerical studies have been carried out in this work to evaluate the efficiency of the proposed sensorless control system.

This paper is organized as follows. In the second section, the mathematical model of the ship electric propulsion system is established. The principle of the high-frequency voltage signal-injection-based sensorless vector control scheme is introduced in the third section. In this section the design of the PMSM position/speed estimator is described in detail. The fourth section presents the establishment and validation of the proposed sensorless control system for ship electric propulsion via Matlab/Simulink tools. Finally, discussions are given and conclusions are drawn in the fifth section.

sec.title: Mathematical model of the ship electric propulsion system
sec.p: A typical electric ship propulsion system is schematically shown in Figure 1. In real ships there are prime movers, multiple generators, dual motors, and multiple conduction paths,4 which are not shown in the simplified diagram. The propulsion system mainly consists of an electric part (the prime mover and generator) and a propulsion part (the motor driver, propulsion motor and propeller). In this work, we focus on the mathematical model of the propulsion part.

caption.p: The PMSM-based ship electric propulsion system.

sec.p: The voltage equation of PMSM at the actual dq synchronous reference frame can be described as
The dq flux linkage equation is
The electromagnetic torque of the motor is
The relation of moment and motor speed is

where ud,q and id,q are direct and quadrature components of stator voltage and current respectively; Ld and Lq are direct and quadrature components of stator inductances respectively; Ra, ωr and ψf denote stator resistance, angular shaft speed and flux linkage due to permanent magnet, respectively; J, TL, B and pn denote the moment of inertia, external load torque, viscous friction coefficient of the rotating parts and poles of machine, respectively; p denotes differential operator and pψf=0.

To propel the ship, the PMSM provides the torque directly to the propeller. Then the propeller generates the thrust force to drive the ship via the thrust bearing. Hence, the propulsion PMSM, propeller, and the hull together constitute the propulsion subsystem in the ship electric propulsion system. The load of the PMSM is the hull resistance that the propeller thrust needs to overcome.
The hydrodynamic characteristic of the propeller–hull can be expressed as26

where k1 is the accompanying stream coefficient, m is the hull mass, vs is the ship speed, P is the propeller thrust, Td is the thrust deduction coefficient, Rf is the hull resistance, k2 is the hull resistance coefficient, ρ is the seawater density, Dp is the propeller diameter, kp is the thrust coefficient, and n is the propeller rotation speed (n = ωr).
The load torque of the propeller is
where km is the torque coefficient. The load torque Mp is equal to PMSM external load TL.

sec.title: Position sensorless control of ship electric propulsion systems
sec.p: As usual in control strategy, the direct reference current is set to zero and then the motor torque is controlled by the quadrature current referring to equations (3) and (4).22Figure 2 illustrates the proposed sensorless vector control approach for the ship electric propulsion system, where the high-frequency voltage signal injection approach is introduced to estimate the rotor position.

caption.p: Block diagram of sensorless drive system of a ship electric propulsion.
DC: direct current; PMSM: permanent magnet synchronous motor. SVPWM: space vector pulse width modulation

sec.p: In sensorless control using the high-frequency voltage injection, the estimated dq synchronous reference frame is used instead of the actual one. This is because the actual rotor position is unknown.28 The principle of the high-frequency voltage signal injection is to inject a high-frequency cosine voltage signal into the d axis of the estimated rotor reference frame, and then to modulate the amplitude of the current in the q axis to obtain the input of the rotor position observer. Thus the rotor position/speed can be estimated by a bang-bang controller or a proportional–integral (PI) controller.28
The voltage equations of a PMSM in equation (1) can be rewritten as
Since the fundamental harmonics of the PMSM do not have any high-frequency component, they can be neglected and equation (7) can be simplified as

where udh,qh and idh,qh are direct and quadrature high-frequency components of stator voltage and current respectively; Rdh,qh and Ldh,qh are direct and quadrature components of stator high-frequency resistance and inductance respectively. Given that the stator high-frequency resistance is much smaller than the high-frequency inductance, equation (8) can be approximated to be
Define the position error as

where θr and θ⌢r are the rotor position in actual and estimated dq synchronous reference frames, respectively. In the rest of the text, the superscript ‘’ denotes variables in the estimated dq synchronous reference frame. Then, in the estimated dq synchronous reference frame, the relationship of the high-frequency stator voltage and current is
Define the average inductance and difference inductance as
Then, equation (11) can be rewritten as
If the injection high-frequency voltage is
substituting equation (14) into equation (13) yields

It can be seen from equation (15) that in an interior PMSM (Ld≠Lq) the rotor position information is contained in both the direct and quadrature high-frequency components of stator current due to the saliency effect. If the position error is small enough, i.e. the estimated dq axis is consistent with the actual dq axis, i⌢qh equals zero. Thus, only rotor position information is left in the quadrature component of stator current and thus the position/speed can be estimated using the q-axis current.28,29

In order to calculate the input of the position/speed estimation, a signal processing procedure is needed to obtain the information on Δθ. For this purpose, a band-pass filter (BPF) is firstly used to extract i⌢qh from the q-axis current. Then multiply i⌢qh with item sin(ωht) to yield equation (16)
A low-pass filter (LPF) is adopted to filter the above signal to get the rotor position estimation error
If Δθ is sufficiently small,sin(2Δθ)≈Δθ, and thus iΔθ in equation (17) can be linearized as
Then a PI controller is used to eliminate the position error to zero, as such the rotor speed can be obtained using the following equations29
The block diagram of the rotor position/speed estimator using a PI controller is shown in Figure 3.

caption.p: The block diagram of the PI controller-based rotor position/speed estimator.
BPF: band pass filter; LPF: low-pass filter; PI: proportional–integral.

sec.title: Simulation result and analysis
sec.p: To validate the newly developed position sensorless control scheme for the ship electric propulsion system, the numeric simulations have been implemented in this paper. The simulation model has been established using the Matlab/Simulink tool according to Figures 2 and 3.

The simulation parameters are: the PMSM stator resistance Ra = 2.875 Ω, direct inductance Ld = 0.087 H, quadrature inductance Lq = 0.11 H, flux linkage ψf = 0.175 Wb, pole pairs Pn = 3, motor friction factor B = 0.1, and motor inertia J = 0.12 kg m2. The hull mass m = 20,000 kg, propeller diameter Dp = 3.6 m, and the coefficients k1, k2, kp and km are selected using empirical values. The injected high-frequency voltage signal is u⌢dh, where t is time in seconds.

The model has been tested under free-running and astern conditions. In the free-running operation, in order to evaluate the performance of the proposed control method in zero–low speed range, the speed reference stepped from the initial value of 100 rpm down-to 5 rpm. In the astern condition, the speed reference shifted from an initial 30 rpm to −30 rpm.

Figures 4 to 6 show the numerical test results of the position sensorless control for the electrically propelled ship in the free-running operation. The motor stator currents shown in Figure 4 in the static three-phase reference frame present good sinusoidal waves while Figure 5 reveals that the space traces of the stator currents i⌢α and i⌢β, and the high-frequency current components i⌢αh and i⌢βh in the α–β reference frame are close to circular traces. These results directly indicate that a high-quality stator-flux-oriented vector control has been achieved. This statement can also be confirmed by the PMSM rotation speed shown in Figure 6(a). It can be seen in the figure that the proposed control scheme can track the speed reference accurately in the steady state though obvious overshooting appears at the motor start. The overshooting phenomenon is mainly caused by the interaction of the propeller and water. The rotor position estimation performance is given in Figure 6(c) and (d). It is noticeable that the high-frequency voltage injection works well even when the propeller rotates at a very low speed (e.g. 5 rpm). The estimated position error Δθ is no greater than 0.3 rad.

caption.p: PMSM stator currents in the actual static three-phase reference frame in free-running condition.
The space traces of the PMSM stator currents: (a)i⌢α and i⌢β, and (b)i⌢αh and i⌢βh.

High-frequency voltage signal injection under ship free-running condition: (a) PMSM rotation speed, (b) motor electromagnetic torque Te and load torque TL, (c) rotor estimated position θ⌢r and actual position θr, and (d) rotor position error Δθ.PMSM: permanent magnet synchronous motor.

sec.p: The simulation test results of the electrically propelled ship in the astern operation are shown in Figures 7 to 9. The motor stator currents shown in Figure 7 present good sinusoidal waves in the static three-phase reference frame. The circular space traces of the stator currents in the α–β reference frame are observed in Figure 9. When the motor reverses, the space trace of i⌢d,q (see Figure 9(a)) distorts severely. However, when the motor speed tends to be stable, it quickly becomes circular. The PMSM rotation speed shown in Figure 9(a) suggests that the proposed sensorless control method works well at low forward and reverse speeds. It is noticed in Figure 9(c) and (d) that, although the position phase reverses direction with the motor reversal, the proposed position estimator could track the rotor position precisely with an error less than 0.3 rad.

caption.p: PMSM stator currents in the actual static three-phase reference frame in astern condition.
The space traces of the PMSM stator currents: (a)i⌢α and i⌢β, and (b)i⌢αh and i⌢βh.

High-frequency voltage signal injection under ship astern condition: (a) PMSM rotation speed, (b) motor electromagnetic torque Te and load torque TL, (c) rotor estimated position θ⌢r and actual position θr, and (d) rotor position error Δθ.PMSM: permanent magnet synchronous motor.

sec.p: To compare the proposed position estimation approach with the back EMF-based method, the popular model reference adaptive system (MRAS) sensorless scheme30 has been used to control the ship electric propulsion system in this work. The principle of the MRAS has been illustrated clearly in Schauder’s work.30 The simulation result using the MRAS-based sensorless control of the ship electric propulsion system in the free-running operation is shown in Figure 10. It can be seen that the MRAS position estimator functions well at high motor speeds but fails to work functionally at low speeds.

caption.p: PMSM stator currents in the actual static three-phase coordinates using MRAS scheme.

sec.title: Discussion and conclusion
sec.p: Owing to the sensorless control strategy, the ship electric propulsion system can have a compact structure with enhanced reliability and maintainability. Since electrically propelled ships require a wide speed regulation, the industry also demands sensorless controllers which can work well at low motor speeds. This is because the ships often operate in a high torque and low speed condition. The high-frequency signal injection method meets the electrically propelled ships’ requirements because it can estimate the propulsion PMSM rotor position accurately even at zero–low speed. The numerical investigations carried out in this work show that the high-frequency signal-injection-based sensorless control can provide high performance for the electrically propelled ship. In Figures 6(c) to (d) and 9(c) to (d), the rotor position has been estimated precisely at both a very low speed (i.e. 5 rpm) and motor reversal. The maximum position error is less than 0.3 rad and the average position error is 0.22 rad. The tracking results of the given rotor speed reference in Figures 6(a) and 9(a) demonstrate that the stator-flux-oriented vector control performs well with the estimated rotor position/speed information. In contrast to the high-frequency signal-injection-based sensorless control, the back EMF-based MRAS algorithm cannot achieve satisfactory control outcomes for the ship electric propulsion system. The back EMF voltage is too small to be detected in the low rotor speed region and thus the MRAS is unstable when the ship propeller operates at a very low speed. Figure 10 has validated the above observation and suggests that generally the back EMF-based position sensorless schemes are suitable for medium- and high-speed applications. From the numerical test results, it is demonstrated that the proposed sensorless scheme has good rotor position/speed estimation precision and thus provides highly efficient control performance for ship electric propulsion systems.

Electric drives for ship propulsion systems can eliminate the mechanical shaft line while increasing ship power system flexibility. As ship electric drives attract more and more attention with their potentially high performance, understanding key issues of optimized ship propulsion system design has been a subject of great interest in the marine industry. The contribution of this work is to introduce the high-frequency voltage signal-injection-based sensorless control into the ship electric propulsion system to realize sensorless control of the system ranging from a high motor rotation speed to zero–low speed. The effectiveness of the proposed control scheme has been validated using the numerical simulations. Since the behavior of the propulsion system is greatly influenced by the performance of the control system, the ship electric propulsion system could benefit from such a position sensorless motor control strategy in terms of a number of advantages including low noise, easy operation, high energy efficiency and low pollution and gas emission, etc. Further validation of the proposed sensorless control approach for ship electric propulsion systems will be investigated via laboratory experiments and field measurements in future work. The outcomes will be reported in due course.

ack.p: The authors are grateful to Dr Kan Liu at the University of Sheffield, UK, for his assistance in the numerical investigations. The authors also thank the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC) for the financial support to the project.
